My favourite answer to this opening.
It looked like a defensive starting by my rival.
He didn't want my bishop bothering, neither did I.
6. Nd5 Nxd5 7.exd5 was a variation that didn't worry me at first, so I continued developing my pieces and preparing to castle.
Before starting the fight for the center...
He wanted his king to be protected too.
Wait a minute. A weakness in the long diagonal?

Looking for a better position for his knight.
Now, the mid game. He had an useless white bishop, which gave me a small advantage in the board, didn't it?

Kd5!?
I could also have taken with my bishop or my c-pawn.
But they were in good positions and f4 was a very attractive square.
Correct decision? Let's see.
Useless anywhere else, and allowing a discovered attack.
